p: In tundra ecosystems, wildfires reduce the abundance of lichens for decades. The long time needed for developing the late-succession fruticose lichens representing the primary caribou forage makes the caribou avoid previously burned tundra habitats in mid-winter for up to 55 years [ 6]. This is not much less than the 76 years needed for full reestablishment of perennial plant cover in the American Southwest Mojave and Sonoran deserts [ 52]. Given the likely climate warming and changing fire patterns, it is predicted that the Central Arctic caribou herd wintering primarily in the arctic tundra can expect 11% reduction in lichen-producing winter habitats [ 53].
